# Arpeggio: 6th in D (Shape: G)

## Brief Presentation
The arpeggio of the 6th in D played using the G shape is a useful and beautiful musical idea that is commonly used in various styles of music. An arpeggio is a broken chord where the notes of a chord are played individually in succession rather than simultaneously. In this case, the arpeggio is based on the 6th note of the D major scale.

## Notes and Intervals
The 6th note in the D major scale is a B note. When played in the G shape on the guitar, the arpeggio consists of the following notes: B (1st string, 7th fret), D (2nd string, 7th fret), G (3rd string, 7th fret), B (4th string, 8th fret), D (5th string, 7th fret), B (6th string, 7th fret). This arpeggio creates a beautiful and melodic sound that can be used to add color and texture to your playing.

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The arpeggio of the 6th in D using the G shape can be used in various genres of music, including pop, rock, jazz, and more. It adds a sense of depth and emotion to your playing, creating a rich and lush sound that can evoke different moods depending on how it is played. Whether used as a standalone melody or as part of a chord progression, this arpeggio can help you create beautiful and expressive music.

## Songs
Here are three songs that use the arpeggio of the 6th in D (G shape) to create unique musical expressions:

1. **"Wonderwall" by Oasis** – This iconic song features a memorable arpeggiated intro that incorporates the arpeggio of the 6th in D played with the G shape, adding a distinct and emotional flavor to the music.
   
2. **"Blackbird" by The Beatles** – In this classic Beatles song, the arpeggio of the 6th in D (G shape) is used to create a beautiful and intricate guitar part that enhances the overall melody and adds depth to the song.
   
3. **"Stop This Train" by John Mayer** – John Mayer uses the arpeggio of the 6th in D (G shape) in this heartfelt ballad to create a moving and introspective guitar accompaniment that complements the soulful lyrics of the song.

By studying and incorporating the arpeggio of the 6th in D using the G shape into your own playing, you can add a new dimension to your music and enhance your ability to express yourself through the guitar.
